Award.AwardTitle: Microlocal Analysis of Linear and Nonlinear Problems
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project develops and applies tools from the field of mathematics known as microlocal analysis. Roughly speaking, microlocal analysis devises methods to keep track of the position and frequency (or momentum) of waves (or, more generally, functions) simultaneously. The project's applications are to wave propagation and other related phenomena, as well as to inverse problems for determining a function from integrals along curves (the X-ray transform) and related problems for determining the structure of a material from boundary measurements. Although the project itself concerns their mathematical theory, the problems under investigation are closely connected to the physical world. Wave propagation is ubiquitous in nature, with electromagnetic waves, such as light, being one of the most prevalent examples. The theory of general relativity is another important physical example via (the recently detected) gravitational waves. Scattering theory for quantum particles (such as protons and electrons) is another subject governed by microlocal analysis, aspects of which enter into the description of both quantum waves at large distances and semiclassical phenomena (those in which Planck's constant can be regarded as small, often the case in chemistry). The inverse problems under study are also of broad significance. One application of the theory under development here is the determination of an unknown variable sound speed in an object via the measurement of travel times of waves, which for instance is relevant to imaging to interior of Earth using the travel times of earthquake waves.

Parts of this project describe the long-time or far-field behavior of waves on curved space-times. Physically these arise in scattering theory and general relativity, including electromagnetic waves on a curved background. The microlocal approach to analysis on these spaces has made breakthroughs possible in work on linear and nonlinear problems on asymptotically (real) hyperbolic spaces as well as on Kerr-de Sitter space. The projects here aim to improve the understanding of Lorentzian scattering spaces, which include asymptotically Minkowski spaces (asymptotically flat spaces, which our universe approximates, at least locally, even if there is a small positive cosmological constant). Other projects concern the behavior of waves at edges -- specifically, the diffraction of the Rayleigh (surface) waves of elasticity. Yet another main area is inverse problems, building on recently-developed tools for spatially localized inversion of the geodesic X-ray transform, including the solution of fixed conformal class boundary rigidity: under suitable assumptions, one can determine a variable sound speed inside an object from the travel times of waves between points on the surface. The parts of the project in this area aim to extend the foregoing result to tensors, which describe anisotropic sound speeds in an appropriate sense; namely, the project will investigate boundary rigidity, for example, recovering a Riemannian metric from its boundary distance function.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project was to use phase space, or microlocal, techniques to analyze various problems. In physical problems, these microlocal techniques keep track of position and momentum at the same time, to the extent that it is allowed by the Heisenberg uncertainty principle.

A typical application is to describe wave-type equations, including the asymptotic behavior far away. Wave-type equations describe, for instance, the propagation of electromagnetic (light), elastic and gravitational waves. The results of the project describe how waves behave.

One of the applications was for the analysis of scattering theory and the Einstein equation on Kerr space-times. These are rotating black hole space-times that describe an asymptotically flat universe; they are thus good approximations of isolated stellar mass black holes. Earlier collaborative work of the PI showed the stability of analogous black holes in space-times with a positive cosmological constant (which is currently understood to be the case for our universe); these are called Kerr-de Sitter black holes. In the current project, with collaborators, the linear techniques were extended to the case of an asymptotically flat universe and were used to show, for instance, the linearized stability of black holes.

Along the way a new approach to scattering theory was established. While typically the latter studies the quantum mechanical scattering of particles such as electrons, mathematically the same structure is relevant for the description of light or gravitational waves. Thus, this new approach was immensely useful for the black hole projects, where one has to understand gravitational phenomena.

Another application is to inverse problems. In earth sciences a common way to obtain information about the interior of Earth is via seismic (elastic) waves which travel through this interior. A relatively simple quantity one can measure is the travel time of waves generated by earthquakes to far away locations on the surface of the Earth; the inverse problem is to find out the propagation speed of waves in the interior (and thus infer what the materials and physical conditions are). In this project a mathematically precise analysis of a slightly simplified problem was given; this simplification is assuming that the materials are transversely isotropic, i.e. have a preferred axis, around which they are rotationally symmetric, which is expected to be the case on sufficiently large scales in effective models of the Earth. The results roughly give that the travel times indeed determine, even when only localized information is given, certain aspects, such as the axis of isotropy and some material parameters, of the structure inside (at least locally, if only local information is given) under suitable conditions, and indeed they do so in such a way that potentially one can implement the result numerically. Ongoing work, with a PhD student, aims to remove some of the limitations on the recovery of the material parameters.

Another result of the project, jointly with a postdoc, was for an inverse problem that incorporates aspects of wave propagation: determining solutions of wave-type equations from integrals along light-ray segments. This relates to the Sachs-Wolfe effect for cosmic background radiation, and is a novel way of going beyond the known limitations of light-ray integrals (transforms).

An important part of this project was to provide research experience to PhD students and develop the research skills of postdocs, as well as to communicate the results in a manner that is accessible to a broader mathematical audience.
